ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: There was no debate of globalization, just Professor Zedillo's opinions.
Weekly class presentations on different elements of globalization and their critics and advantages

This class gives a pretty good insight into the world trading system and the issues surrounding it. You will be able to talk much more in depth about key current events like trade wars, migration and the WTO afterwards. For those who want more than the surface level presentation of these issues in the media, it is a good class.
Learned more about globalization and how this system is currently threatened

This course was a rigorous exploration of theories arguing for globalisation. As someone without experience in trade theory, it was quite challenging, but the course was a good exploration into arguments for globalisation.

I learned about the origins of globalization, how it has evolved, its benefits and the pushbacks it has received. I learned about important concepts in international trade, in multilateralism and significant agreements and innovations that transformed globalization

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course needs more debate and fewer presentations.

The assigned readings were engaging, interesting, and relevant to understanding the debate around globalization. The reading response assignments were well structured to help us digest each week's information. 

I wish we would have had more time for class discussion on certain topics, student presentations were often too long.

Strengths: prof Zedillo is an amazing professor and it is really special to be in a seminar with him. The topics are interesting! 
Weaknesses: it would have been nice to have more regular opportunities for class discussions; we also barely got any feedback or grades throughout the semester

The presentations that I did forced me to deeply understand the material, and I think they were useful. I do wish we could have had a little bit more debate in class (maybe a smaller classroom would've facilitated that better), and having more feedback would've been helpful as well.
Improves your discussion and presentation skills

The course definitely skewed towards the pro-globalisation camp, and oftentimes I felt that there was not enough critiques of neoliberalism and explorations of globalisation outside of traditional economic theory, and personally I feel that a course titled Debating Globalisation should explore other perspectives in greater depth.

Additionally, a though we submitted work every week, we got little to no feedback, and got no instruction about our final pape, which is good for some students but can be a bit disorienting for others.

However, I really enjoyed how current events focused the course was, and how flexible the class was in responding to global events.

Strengths: Very logical order and classes build up on each other, establishing theoretical frameworks and then analyzing contemporary topics 

Weaknesses: No feedback, quality of each class depends on student presentations

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. Professor Zedillo was uncooperative and didn't address the cultural implications of globalization. He was unwilling to listen to different opinions and actually debate globalization.
Yes, it was great! And you should definitely take the opportunity to learn from prof Zedillo!

I would recommend this class if you are interested in going deep into issues of international trade and the WTO. If you are interested in taking a broad view of trade from an economic, political, and historical perspective, then this class is for you - if not then you won't enjoy it as much. I have found this class really bolstered my understanding of a lot of international issues in the world today.
Yes - interesting class and material, but not a lot of feedback was given
Yes, President Zedillo is an extremely accomplished and kind man, he is an expert in this area and it is very valuable to hear his stories in class
